category.template: The inputs and attrs of the node object is based on the TensorFlow op registry.

category.pattern: HERE IS AN EXAMPLE OF REGISTERING A NEW MATMUL OP
category.template: Here is an example of registering a new MatMul Op.

category.pattern: REGISTER AN OP FOR GRAPH MODEL EXECUTOR . THIS ALLOW YOU TO REGISTER TENSORFLOW CUSTOM OP OR OVERRIDE EXISTING OP
category.template: Register an Op for graph model executor. This allow you to register TensorFlow custom op or override existing op.

category.pattern: RETRIEVE THE OPMAPPER OBJECT FOR THE REGISTERED OP
category.template: Retrieve the OpMapper object for the registered op.

category.pattern: DEREGISTER THE OP FOR GRAPH MODEL EXECUTOR
category.template: Deregister the Op for graph model executor.

category.pattern: THEY ARE MOST OFTEN ENCOUNTERED WHEN BUILDING A GRAPH OF LAYERS FOR A A TF.LAYERSMODEL AND THE INPUT DATA S SHAPE BUT NOT VALUES ARE KNOWN
category.template: They are most often encountered when building a graph of Layers for a a tf.LayersModel and the input data's shape, but not values are known.

category.pattern: TF.SYMBOLICTENSOR IS A PLACEHOLDER FOR A TENSOR WITHOUT ANY CONCRETE VALUE
category.template: tf.SymbolicTensor is a placeholder for a Tensor without any concrete value.

category.pattern: PRINT A TEXT SUMMARY OF THE SEQUENTIAL MODEL S LAYERS
category.template: Print a text summary of the Sequential model's layers.

category.pattern: ADDS A LAYER INSTANCE ON TOP OF THE LAYER STACK
category.template: Adds a layer instance on top of the layer stack.

category.pattern: TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) IS A FACTORY FUNCTION THAT CREATES AN INSTANCE OF TF.SEQUENTIAL
category.template: tf.sequential() is a factory function that creates an instance of tf.Sequential.

category.pattern: A MODEL WITH A STACK OF LAYERS FEEDING LINEARLY FROM ONE TO THE NEXT
category.template: A model with a stack of layers, feeding linearly from one to the next.

category.pattern: IF BOTH NAME AND INDEX ARE SPECIFIED INDEX TAKES PRECEDENCE
category.template: If both name and index are specified, index takes precedence.

category.pattern: INDICES ARE BASED ON ORDER OF HORIZONTAL GRAPH TRAVERSAL ( BOTTOM-UP )
category.template: Indices are based on order of horizontal graph traversal (bottom-up).

category.pattern: RETRIEVES A LAYER BASED ON EITHER ITS NAME ( UNIQUE ) OR INDEX
category.template: Retrieves a layer based on either its name (unique) or index.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 4 . SEND MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS TO AN HTTP SERVER . SEE THE DOCUMENTATION OF TF.IO.HTTP ( ) FOR MORE DETAILS INCLUDING SPECIFYING REQUEST PARAMETERS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SERVER
category.template: Example 4. Send model's topology and weights to an HTTP server. See the documentation of tf.io.http() for more details including specifying request parameters and implementation of the server.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 3 . SAVING MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS AS TWO FILES ( MY-MODEL-1.JSON AND MY-MODEL-1.WEIGHTS.BIN ) DOWNLOADED FROM BROWSER
category.template: Example 3. Saving model's topology and weights as two files (my-model-1.json and my-model-1.weights.bin) downloaded from browser.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 2 . SAVING MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS TO BROWSER INDEXEDDB ; THEN LOAD IT BACK
SAVE THE CONFIGURATION AND / OR WEIGHTS OF THE LAYERSMODEL
category.template: Save the configuration and/or weights of the LayersModel.

category.pattern: RUNS A SINGLE GRADIENT UPDATE ON A SINGLE BATCH OF DATA
category.template: Runs a single gradient update on a single batch of data.

category.pattern: TOTAL NUMBER OF BATCHES OF SAMPLES TO DRAW FROM VALIDATIONDATA FOR VALIDATION PURPOSE BEFORE STOPPING AT THE END OF EVERY EPOCH . IF NOT SPECIFIED EVALUATEDATASET WILL USE ITERATOR.NEXT ( ) . DONE AS SIGNAL TO STOP VALIDATION
category.template: Total number of batches of samples to draw from validationData for validation purpose before stopping at the end of every epoch. If not specified, evaluateDataset will use iterator.next().done as signal to stop validation.

category.pattern: IF NOT SPECIFIED ITS VALUE DEFAULTS TO 32
category.template: If not specified, its value defaults to 32.

category.pattern: USED ONLY IF VALIDATIONDATA IS AN ARRAY OF TF.TENSOR OBJECTS I.E . NOT A DATASET OBJECT
category.template: Used only if validationData is an array of tf.Tensor objects, i.e., not a dataset object.

category.pattern: THE MODEL WILL NOT BE TRAINED ON THIS DATA
category.template: The model will not be trained on this data.

category.pattern: IF VALIDATIONDATA IS A DATASET OBJECT AND THE VALIDATIONBATCHES PARAMETER IS SPECIFIED THE VALIDATION WILL USE VALIDATIONBATCHES BATCHES DRAWN FROM THE DATASET OBJECT . IF VALIDATIONBATCHES PARAMETER IS NOT SPECIFIED THE VALIDATION WILL STOP WHEN THE DATASET IS EXHAUSTED
category.template: If validationData is a dataset object, and the validationBatches parameter is specified, the validation will use validationBatches batches drawn from the dataset object. If validationBatches parameter is not specified, the validation will stop when the dataset is exhausted.

category.pattern: TRAINS THE MODEL USING A DATASET OBJECT
category.template: Trains the model using a dataset object.

category.pattern: IN THE BROWSER ENVIRONMENT YIELDING THE MAIN THREAD CAN IMPROVE THE RESPONSIVENESS OF THE PAGE DURING TRAINING . IN THE NODE.JS ENVIRONMENT IT CAN ENSURE TASKS QUEUED IN THE EVENT LOOP CAN BE HANDLED IN A TIMELY MANNER
category.template: In the browser environment, yielding the main thread can improve the responsiveness of the page during training. In the Node.js environment, it can ensure tasks queued in the event loop can be handled in a timely manner.

category.pattern: IF THE MODEL HAS MULTIPLE OUTPUTS A CLASS WEIGHT CAN BE SPECIFIED FOR EACH OF THE OUTPUTS BY SETTING THIS FIELD AN ARRAY OF WEIGHT OBJECT OR A OBJECT THAT MAPS MODEL OUTPUT NAMES ( E.G . MODEL.OUTPUTNAMES [ 0 ] ) TO WEIGHT OBJECTS
category.template: If the model has multiple outputs, a class weight can be specified for each of the outputs by setting this field an array of weight object or a object that maps model output names (e.g., model.outputNames[0]) to weight objects.

category.pattern: 0 - NO PRINTED MESSAGE DURING FIT ( ) CALL . 1 - IN NODE.JS ( TFJS-NODE ) PRINTS THE PROGRESS BAR TOGETHER WITH REAL-TIME UPDATES OF LOSS AND METRIC VALUES AND TRAINING SPEED . IN THE BROWSER : NO ACTION . THIS IS THE DEFAULT . 2 - NOT IMPLEMENTED YET
category.template: 0 - No printed message during fit() call. 1 - In Node.js (tfjs-node), prints the progress bar, together with real-time updates of loss and metric values and training speed. In the browser: no action. This is the default. 2 - Not implemented yet.

category.pattern: EXPECTED TO BE 0 1 OR 2 . DEFAULT : 1
category.template: Expected to be 0, 1, or 2. Default: 1.

category.pattern: TRAINS THE MODEL FOR A FIXED NUMBER OF EPOCHS ( ITERATIONS ON A DATASET )

random.li: Trains the model for a fixed number of epochs (iterations on a dataset).
Trains the model for a fixed number of epochs (iterations on a dataset).

category.pattern: RETURNS PREDICTIONS FOR A SINGLE BATCH OF SAMPLES
category.template: Returns predictions for a single batch of samples.

category.pattern: NOTE : THE STEP MODE OF PREDICT ( ) IS CURRENTLY NOT SUPPORTED . THIS IS BECAUSE THE TENSORFLOW.JS CORE BACKEND IS IMPERATIVE ONLY
category.template: Note: the "step" mode of predict() is currently not supported. This is because the TensorFlow.js core backend is imperative only.

category.pattern: GENERATES OUTPUT PREDICTIONS FOR THE INPUT SAMPLES
category.template: Generates output predictions for the input samples.

category.pattern: EVALUATE MODEL USING A DATASET OBJECT
category.template: Evaluate model using a dataset object.

category.pattern: COMPUTATION IS DONE IN BATCHES
category.template: Computation is done in batches.

category.pattern: LOSS AND METRICS ARE SPECIFIED DURING COMPILE ( ) WHICH NEEDS TO HAPPEN BEFORE CALLS TO EVALUATE ( )
category.template: Loss and metrics are specified during compile(), which needs to happen before calls to evaluate().

category.pattern: RETURNS THE LOSS VALUE & METRICS VALUES FOR THE MODEL IN TEST MODE
category.template: Returns the loss value & metrics values for the model in test mode.

category.pattern: CONFIGURES AND PREPARES THE MODEL FOR TRAINING AND EVALUATION . COMPILING OUTFITS THE MODEL WITH AN OPTIMIZER LOSS AND / OR METRICS . CALLING FIT OR EVALUATE ON AN UN-COMPILED MODEL WILL THROW AN ERROR
category.template: Configures and prepares the model for training and evaluation. Compiling outfits the model with an optimizer, loss, and/or metrics. Calling fit or evaluate on an un-compiled model will throw an error.

category.pattern: PRINT A TEXT SUMMARY OF THE MODEL S LAYERS
category.template: Print a text summary of the model's layers.

category.pattern: SEE ALSO : TF.SEQUENTIAL TF.LOADLAYERSMODEL ( )
category.template: See also: tf.Sequential, tf.loadLayersModel().

category.pattern: TF.LAYERSMODEL IS THE BASIC UNIT OF TRAINING INFERENCE AND EVALUATION IN TENSORFLOW.JS . TO CREATE A TF.LAYERSMODEL USE TF.LAYERSMODEL
category.template: tf.LayersModel is the basic unit of training, inference and evaluation in TensorFlow.js. To create a tf.LayersModel, use tf.LayersModel.

category.pattern: A TF.LAYERSMODEL IS A DIRECTED ACYCLIC GRAPH OF TF.LAYERS PLUS METHODS FOR TRAINING EVALUATION PREDICTION AND SAVING
category.template: A tf.LayersModel is a directed, acyclic graph of tf.Layers plus methods for training, evaluation, prediction and saving.

category.pattern: RELEASES THE MEMORY USED BY THE WEIGHT TENSORS AND RESOURCEMANAGER
category.template: Releases the memory used by the weight tensors and resourceManager.

category.pattern: DISPOSE INTERMEDIATE TENSORS FOR MODEL DEBUGGING MODE ( FLAG KEEP_INTERMEDIATE_TENSORS IS TRUE )
category.template: Dispose intermediate tensors for model debugging mode (flag KEEP_INTERMEDIATE_TENSORS is true).

category.pattern: GET INTERMEDIATE TENSORS FOR MODEL DEBUGGING MODE ( FLAG KEEP_INTERMEDIATE_TENSORS IS TRUE )
category.template: Get intermediate tensors for model debugging mode (flag KEEP_INTERMEDIATE_TENSORS is true).

category.pattern: EXECUTES INFERENCE FOR THE MODEL FOR GIVEN INPUT TENSORS IN ASYNC FASHION USE THIS METHOD WHEN YOUR MODEL CONTAINS CONTROL FLOW OPS
category.template: Executes inference for the model for given input tensors in async fashion, use this method when your model contains control flow ops.

category.pattern: EXECUTES INFERENCE FOR THE MODEL FOR GIVEN INPUT TENSORS
category.template: Executes inference for the model for given input tensors.

category.pattern: EXECUTE THE INFERENCE FOR THE INPUT TENSORS
category.template: Execute the inference for the input tensors.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 1 : SAVE MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS TO BROWSER LOCAL STORAGE ; THEN LOAD IT BACK
THIS METHOD ALSO ALLOWS YOU TO REFER TO CERTAIN TYPES OF IOHANDLERS AS URL-LIKE STRING SHORTCUTS SUCH AS LOCALSTORAGE : / / AND INDEXEDDB : / /
category.template: This method also allows you to refer to certain types of IOHandlers as URL-like string shortcuts, such as 'localstorage://' and 'indexeddb://'.

category.pattern: THIS METHOD ALSO ALLOWS YOU TO REFER TO CERTAIN TYPES OF IOHANDLERS AS URL-LIKE STRING SHORTCUTS SUCH AS LOCALSTORAGE : / / AND INDEXEDDB : / /
category.template: This method also allows you to refer to certain types of IOHandlers as URL-like string shortcuts, such as 'localstorage://' and 'indexeddb://'.

category.pattern: AN IOHANDLER IS AN OBJECT THAT HAS A SAVE METHOD OF THE PROPER SIGNATURE DEFINED . THE SAVE METHOD MANAGES THE STORING OR TRANSMISSION OF SERIALIZED DATA ( ARTIFACTS ) THAT REPRESENT THE MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS ONTO OR VIA A SPECIFIC MEDIUM SUCH AS FILE DOWNLOADS LOCAL STORAGE INDEXEDDB IN THE WEB BROWSER AND HTTP REQUESTS TO A SERVER . TENSORFLOW.JS PROVIDES IOHANDLER IMPLEMENTATIONS FOR A NUMBER OF FREQUENTLY USED SAVING MEDIUMS SUCH AS TF.IO.BROWSERDOWNLOADS ( ) AND TF.IO.BROWSERLOCALSTORAGE . SEE TF.IO FOR MORE DETAILS
category.template: An IOHandler is an object that has a save method of the proper signature defined. The save method manages the storing or transmission of serialized data ("artifacts") that represent the model's topology and weights onto or via a specific medium, such as file downloads, local storage, IndexedDB in the web browser and HTTP requests to a server. TensorFlow.js provides IOHandler implementations for a number of frequently used saving mediums, such as tf.io.browserDownloads() and tf.io.browserLocalStorage. See tf.io for more details.

category.pattern: SAVE THE CONFIGURATION AND / OR WEIGHTS OF THE GRAPHMODEL
category.template: Save the configuration and/or weights of the GraphModel.

category.pattern: SYNCHRONOUSLY CONSTRUCT THE IN MEMORY WEIGHT MAP AND COMPILE THE INFERENCE GRAPH . ALSO INITIALIZE HASHTABLE IF ANY
category.template: Synchronously construct the in memory weight map and compile the inference graph. Also initialize hashtable if any.

category.pattern: A TF.GRAPHMODEL CAN ONLY BE CREATED BY LOADING FROM A MODEL CONVERTED FROM A TENSORFLOW SAVEDMODEL USING THE COMMAND LINE CONVERTER TOOL AND LOADED VIA TF.LOADGRAPHMODEL ( )
category.template: A tf.GraphModel can only be created by loading from a model converted from a TensorFlow SavedModel using the command line converter tool and loaded via tf.loadGraphModel().

category.pattern: A TF.GRAPHMODEL IS A DIRECTED ACYCLIC GRAPH BUILT FROM A SAVEDMODEL GRAPHDEF AND ALLOWS INFERENCE EXECUTION
category.template: A tf.GraphModel is a directed, acyclic graph built from a SavedModel GraphDef and allows inference execution.

category.pattern: SEE ALSO : TF.LAYERSMODEL TF.SEQUENTIAL TF.LOADLAYERSMODEL ( )
category.template: See also: tf.LayersModel, tf.Sequential, tf.loadLayersModel().

category.pattern: A TF.FUNCTIONAL IS AN ALIAS TO TF.LAYERSMODEL
category.template: A tf.Functional is an alias to tf.LayersModel.

category.pattern: THIS IS OFTEN USED FOR REGISTERING CUSTOM LAYERS SO THEY CAN BE SERIALIZED AND DESERIALIZED
category.template: This is often used for registering custom Layers, so they can be serialized and deserialized.

category.pattern: REGISTER A CLASS WITH THE SERIALIZATION MAP OF TENSORFLOW.JS
category.template: Register a class with the serialization map of TensorFlow.js.

category.pattern: REMOVE A MODEL SPECIFIED BY URL FROM A REIGSTERED STORAGE MEDIUM
category.template: Remove a model specified by URL from a reigstered storage medium.

category.pattern: MOVE A MODEL FROM ONE URL TO ANOTHER
category.template: Move a model from one URL to another.

category.pattern: FOR A WEB BROWSER ENVIRONMENT THE REGISTERED MEDIUMS ARE LOCAL STORAGE AND INDEXEDDB
category.template: For a web browser environment, the registered mediums are Local Storage and IndexedDB.

category.pattern: LIST ALL MODELS STORED IN REGISTERED STORAGE MEDIUMS
category.template: List all models stored in registered storage mediums.

category.pattern: COPY A MODEL FROM ONE URL TO ANOTHER
category.template: Copy a model from one URL to another.

category.pattern: LOAD A GRAPH MODEL GIVEN A SYNCHRONOUS IO HANDLER WITH A LOAD METHOD
category.template: Load a graph model given a synchronous IO handler with a 'load' method.

category.pattern: THE FOLLOWING GITHUB GIST HTTPS://GIST.GITHUB.COM/DSMILKOV/1B6046FD6132D7408D5257B0976F7864 IMPLEMENTS A SERVER BASED ON FLASK THAT CAN RECEIVE THE REQUEST . UPON RECEIVING THE MODEL ARTIFACTS VIA THE REQUST THIS PARTICULAR SERVER RECONSISTUTES INSTANCES OF KERAS MODELS IN MEMORY
category.template: The following GitHub Gist https://gist.github.com/dsmilkov/1b6046fd6132d7408d5257b0976f7864 implements a server based on flask that can receive the request. Upon receiving the model artifacts via the requst, this particular server reconsistutes instances of Keras Models in memory.

category.pattern: CREATES AN IOHANDLER SUBTYPE THAT SENDS MODEL ARTIFACTS TO HTTP SERVER
category.template: Creates an IOHandler subtype that sends model artifacts to HTTP server.

category.pattern: THIS METHOD CAN BE USED FOR LOADING FROM FILES SUCH AS USER-SELECTED FILES IN THE BROWSER . WHEN USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH TF.LOADLAYERSMODEL ( ) AN INSTANCE OF TF.LAYERSMODEL ( KERAS-STYLE ) CAN BE CONSTRUCTED FROM THE LOADED ARTIFACTS
category.template: This method can be used for loading from files such as user-selected files in the browser. When used in conjunction with tf.loadLayersModel(), an instance of tf.LayersModel (Keras-style) can be constructed from the loaded artifacts.

category.pattern: CREATES AN IOHANDLER THAT LOADS MODEL ARTIFACTS FROM USER-SELECTED FILES
category.template: Creates an IOHandler that loads model artifacts from user-selected files.

category.pattern: THE RETURNED IOHANDLER INSTANCE CAN BE USED AS MODEL EXPORTING METHODS SUCH AS TF.MODEL.SAVE AND SUPPORTS ONLY SAVING
category.template: The returned IOHandler instance can be used as model exporting methods such as tf.Model.save and supports only saving.

category.pattern: CREATES AN IOHANDLER THAT TRIGGERS FILE DOWNLOADS FROM THE BROWSER
category.template: Creates an IOHandler that triggers file downloads from the browser.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 4 . LOAD A MODEL FROM USER-SELECTED FILES FROM HTML FILE INPUT ELEMENTS
category.template: Example 4. Load a model from user-selected files from HTML file input elements.

category.pattern: EXAMPLE 3 . SAVING MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS TO BROWSER INDEXEDDB ; THEN LOAD IT BACK
EXAMPLE 2 : SAVE MODEL S TOPOLOGY AND WEIGHTS TO BROWSER LOCAL STORAGE ; THEN LOAD IT BACK
EXAMPLE 1 . LOAD A MODEL FROM AN HTTP SERVER
category.template: Example 1. Load a model from an HTTP server.

category.pattern: THIS MODE IS NOT APPLICABLE TO TENSORFLOW SAVEDMODELS OR THEIR CONVERTED FORMS . FOR THOSE MODELS USE TF.LOADGRAPHMODEL ( )
category.template: This mode is not applicable to TensorFlow SavedModels or their converted forms. For those models, use tf.loadGraphModel().

category.pattern: LOAD A MODEL COMPOSED OF LAYER OBJECTS INCLUDING ITS TOPOLOGY AND OPTIONALLY WEIGHTS . SEE THE TUTORIAL NAMED HOW TO IMPORT A KERAS MODEL FOR USAGE EXAMPLES
category.template: Load a model composed of Layer objects, including its topology and optionally weights. See the Tutorial named "How to import a Keras Model" for usage examples.

category.pattern: WITH THIS FUNC YOU CAN CONVERT THE WEIGHT FILE NAME TO ANY URL
category.template: With this func you can convert the weight file name to any URL.

category.pattern: DEFAULT : FALSE
category.template: Default: false.

category.pattern: SETTING THIS TO TRUE ALLOWS PASSING A TF-HUB MODULE URL OMITTING THE STANDARD MODEL FILE NAME AND THE QUERY PARAMETERS
category.template: Setting this to true allows passing a TF-Hub module URL, omitting the standard model file name and the query parameters.

category.pattern: FOR INSTANCE IF THE PATH TO THE MODEL JSON FILE IS HTTP://LOCALHOST/FOO/MODEL.JSON, THEN THE DEFAULT PATH PREFIX WILL BE HTTP://LOCALHOST/FOO/. IF A WEIGHT FILE HAS THE PATH VALUE GROUP1 - SHARD1OF2 IN THE WEIGHT MANIFEST THEN THE WEIGHT FILE WILL BE LOADED FROM HTTP://LOCALHOST/FOO/GROUP1-SHARD1OF2 BY DEFAULT . HOWEVER IF YOU PROVIDE A WEIGHTPATHPREFIX VALUE OF HTTP://LOCALHOST/FOO/ALT-WEIGHTS, THEN THE WEIGHT FILE WILL BE LOADED FROM THE PATH HTTP://LOCALHOST/FOO/ALT-WEIGHTS/GROUP1-SHARD1OF2 INSTEAD
category.template: For instance, if the path to the model JSON file is http://localhost/foo/model.json, then the default path prefix will be http://localhost/foo/. If a weight file has the path value group1-shard1of2 in the weight manifest, then the weight file will be loaded from http://localhost/foo/group1-shard1of2 by default. However, if you provide a weightPathPrefix value of http://localhost/foo/alt-weights, then the weight file will be loaded from the path http://localhost/foo/alt-weights/group1-shard1of2 instead.

category.pattern: DEFAULT : TRUE
category.template: Default: true.

category.pattern: IF TRUE REQUIRE THAT THE PROVIDED WEIGHTS EXACTLY MATCH THOSE REQUIRED BY THE LAYERS . FALSE MEANS THAT BOTH EXTRA WEIGHTS AND MISSING WEIGHTS WILL BE SILENTLY IGNORED
category.template: If true, require that the provided weights exactly match those required by the layers. false means that both extra weights and missing weights will be silently ignored.

category.pattern: LOAD A GRAPH MODEL GIVEN A URL TO THE MODEL DEFINITION
category.template: Load a graph model given a URL to the model definition.

category.pattern: NOTE : INPUT IS ONLY NECESSARY WHEN USING MODEL . WHEN USING SEQUENTIAL SPECIFY INPUTSHAPE FOR THE FIRST LAYER OR USE INPUTLAYER AS THE FIRST LAYER
category.template: Note: input is only necessary when using model. When using sequential, specify inputShape for the first layer or use inputLayer as the first layer.

category.pattern: USERS SHOULD CALL THE INPUT FACTORY FUNCTION FOR CONSISTENCY WITH OTHER GENERATOR FUNCTIONS
category.template: Users should call the input factory function for consistency with other generator functions.

category.pattern: USED TO INSTANTIATE AN INPUT TO A MODEL AS A TF.SYMBOLICTENSOR
category.template: Used to instantiate an input to a model as a tf.SymbolicTensor.

category.pattern: SEE ALSO : TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) TF.LOADLAYERSMODEL ( )
category.template: See also: tf.sequential(), tf.loadLayersModel().

category.pattern: FOR EXAMPLE THE FOLLOWING CODE SNIPPET DEFINES A MODEL CONSISTING OF TWO DENSE LAYERS WITH 10 AND 4 UNITS RESPECTIVELY
category.template: For example, the following code snippet defines a model consisting of two dense layers, with 10 and 4 units, respectively.

category.pattern: WHEN CREATING A TF.LAYERSMODEL SPECIFY ITS INPUT ( S ) AND OUTPUT ( S ) . LAYERS ARE USED TO WIRE INPUT ( S ) TO OUTPUT ( S )
category.template: When creating a tf.LayersModel, specify its input(s) and output(s). Layers are used to wire input(s) to output(s).

category.pattern: THE KEY DIFFERENCE BETWEEN TF.MODEL ( ) AND TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) IS THAT TF.MODEL ( ) IS MORE GENERIC SUPPORTING AN ARBITRARY GRAPH ( WITHOUT CYCLES ) OF LAYERS . TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) IS LESS GENERIC AND SUPPORTS ONLY A LINEAR STACK OF LAYERS
category.template: The key difference between tf.model() and tf.sequential() is that tf.model() is more generic, supporting an arbitrary graph (without cycles) of layers. tf.sequential() is less generic and supports only a linear stack of layers.

category.pattern: A MODEL IS A DATA STRUCTURE THAT CONSISTS OF LAYERS AND DEFINES INPUTS AND OUTPUTS
category.template: A model is a data structure that consists of Layers and defines inputs and outputs.

category.pattern: THE KEY DIFFERENCE BETWEEN TF.MODEL ( ) AND TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) IS THAT TF.SEQUENTIAL ( ) IS LESS GENERIC SUPPORTING ONLY A LINEAR STACK OF LAYERS . TF.MODEL ( ) IS MORE GENERIC AND SUPPORTS AN ARBITRARY GRAPH ( WITHOUT CYCLES ) OF LAYERS
category.template: The key difference between tf.model() and tf.sequential() is that tf.sequential() is less generic, supporting only a linear stack of layers. tf.model() is more generic and supports an arbitrary graph (without cycles) of layers.

category.pattern: THIS MEANS THAT THE FIRST LAYER PASSED TO A TF.SEQUENTIAL MODEL SHOULD HAVE A DEFINED INPUT SHAPE . WHAT THAT MEANS IS THAT IT SHOULD HAVE RECEIVED AN INPUTSHAPE OR BATCHINPUTSHAPE ARGUMENT OR FOR SOME TYPE OF LAYERS ( RECURRENT DENSE . . . ) AN INPUTDIM ARGUMENT
category.template: This means that the first layer passed to a tf.Sequential model should have a defined input shape. What that means is that it should have received an inputShape or batchInputShape argument, or for some type of layers (recurrent, Dense...) an inputDim argument.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.SEQUENTIAL MODEL . A SEQUENTIAL MODEL IS ANY MODEL WHERE THE OUTPUTS OF ONE LAYER ARE THE INPUTS TO THE NEXT LAYER I.E . THE MODEL TOPOLOGY IS A SIMPLE STACK OF LAYERS WITH NO BRANCHING OR SKIPPING
category.template: Creates a tf.Sequential model. A sequential model is any model where the outputs of one layer are the inputs to the next layer, i.e. the model topology is a simple 'stack' of layers, with no branching or skipping.

category.pattern: THERE ARE TWO PRIMARY WAYS OF CREATING MODELS
category.template: There are two primary ways of creating models.

category.pattern: MODELS ARE A COLLECTION OF LAYERS SEE MODEL CREATION FOR DETAILS ABOUT HOW LAYERS CAN BE CONNECTED
category.template: Models are a collection of Layers, see Model Creation for details about how Layers can be connected.

category.pattern: MODELS ARE ONE OF THE PRIMARY ABSTRACTIONS USED IN TENSORFLOW.JS LAYERS . MODELS CAN BE TRAINED EVALUATED AND USED FOR PREDICTION . A MODEL S STATE ( TOPOLOGY AND OPTIONALLY TRAINED WEIGHTS ) CAN BE RESTORED FROM VARIOUS FORMATS
category.template: Models are one of the primary abstractions used in TensorFlow.js Layers. Models can be trained, evaluated, and used for prediction. A model's state (topology, and optionally, trained weights) can be restored from various formats.

category.pattern: THE GENERATED VALUES FOLLOW A UNIFORM DISTRIBUTION IN THE RANGE [ MINVAL MAXVAL ) . THE LOWER BOUND MINVAL IS INCLUDED IN THE RANGE WHILE THE UPPER BOUND MAXVAL IS EXCLUDED
category.template: The generated values follow a uniform distribution in the range [minval, maxval). The lower bound minval is included in the range, while the upper bound maxval is excluded.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES SAMPLED FROM A UNIFORM DISTRIBUTION
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values sampled from a uniform distribution.

category.pattern: THE GENERATED VALUES WILL HAVE MEAN 0 AND STANDARD DEVIATION 1
category.template: The generated values will have mean 0 and standard deviation 1.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES SAMPLED FROM A NORMAL DISTRIBUTION
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values sampled from a normal distribution.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES SAMPLED FROM A GAMMA DISTRIBUTION
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values sampled from a gamma distribution.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES SAMPLED FROM A RANDOM NUMBER GENERATOR FUNCTION DEFINED BY THE USER
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values sampled from a random number generator function defined by the user.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES DRAWN FROM A MULTINOMIAL DISTRIBUTION
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values drawn from a multinomial distribution.

category.pattern: EINSUM ALLOWS DEFINING TENSORS BY DEFINING THEIR ELEMENT-WISE COMPUTATION . THIS COMPUTATION IS BASED ON EINSTEIN SUMMATION
category.template: einsum allows defining Tensors by defining their element-wise computation. This computation is based on Einstein summation.

category.pattern: TENSOR CONTRACTION OVER SPECIFIED INDICES AND OUTER PRODUCT
category.template: Tensor contraction over specified indices and outer product.

category.pattern: UNSTACKS A TF.TENSOR OF RANK-R INTO A LIST OF RANK- ( R-1 ) TF.TENSORS
category.template: Unstacks a tf.Tensor of rank-R into a list of rank-(R-1) tf.Tensors.

category.pattern: THIS OPERATION CREATES A NEW TENSOR BY REPLICATING INPUT REPS TIMES . THE OUTPUT TENSOR S I TH DIMENSION HAS INPUT.SHAPE [ I ] * REPS [ I ] ELEMENTS AND THE VALUES OF INPUT ARE REPLICATED REPS [ I ] TIMES ALONG THE I TH DIMENSION . FOR EXAMPLE TILING [ A B C D ] BY [ 2 ] PRODUCES [ A B C D A B C D ]
category.template: This operation creates a new tensor by replicating input reps times. The output tensor's i'th dimension has input.shape[i] * reps[i] elements, and the values of input are replicated reps[i] times along the i'th dimension. For example, tiling [a, b, c, d] by [2] produces [a, b, c, d, a, b, c, d].

category.pattern: CONSTRUCT A TENSOR BY REPEATING IT THE NUMBER OF TIMES GIVEN BY REPS
category.template: Construct a tensor by repeating it the number of times given by reps.

category.pattern: STACKS A LIST OF RANK-R TF.TENSORS INTO ONE RANK- ( R + 1 ) TF.TENSOR
category.template: Stacks a list of rank-R tf.Tensors into one rank-(R+1) tf.Tensor.

category.pattern: IF NUMORSIZESPLITS IS A NUMBER ARRAY SPLITS X INTO NUMORSIZESPLITS.LENGTH PIECES . THE SHAPE OF THE I-TH PIECE HAS THE SAME SIZE AS X EXCEPT ALONG DIMENSION AXIS WHERE THE SIZE IS NUMORSIZESPLITS [ I ]
category.template: If numOrSizeSplits is a number array, splits x into numOrSizeSplits.length pieces. The shape of the i-th piece has the same size as x except along dimension axis where the size is numOrSizeSplits[i].

category.pattern: IF NUMORSIZESPLITS IS A NUMBER SPLITS X ALONG DIMENSION AXIS INTO NUMORSIZESPLITS SMALLER TENSORS . REQUIRES THAT NUMORSIZESPLITS EVENLY DIVIDES X.SHAPE [ AXIS ]
category.template: If numOrSizeSplits is a number, splits x along dimension axis into numOrSizeSplits smaller tensors. Requires that numOrSizeSplits evenly divides x.shape[axis].

category.pattern: SPLITS A TF.TENSOR INTO SUB TENSORS
category.template: Splits a tf.Tensor into sub tensors.

category.pattern: EXTRACTS A SLICE FROM A TF.TENSOR STARTING AT COORDINATES BEGIN AND IS OF SIZE SIZE
category.template: Extracts a slice from a tf.Tensor starting at coordinates begin and is of size size.

category.pattern: EXCEPT TF.REVERSE1D ( WHICH DOES NOT HAVE AXIS PARAM ) ALL METHODS HAVE SAME SIGNATURE AS THIS METHOD
category.template: Except tf.reverse1d (which does not have axis param), all methods have same signature as this method.

category.pattern: REVERSES A TF.TENSOR ALONG A SPECIFIED AXIS
category.template: Reverses a tf.Tensor along a specified axis.

category.pattern: GATHER SLICES FROM TENSOR X S AXIS AXIS ACCORDING TO INDICES
category.template: Gather slices from tensor x's axis axis according to indices.

category.pattern: EXCEPT TF.CONCAT1D ( WHICH DOES NOT HAVE AXIS PARAM ) ALL METHODS HAVE SAME SIGNATURE AS THIS METHOD
category.template: Except tf.concat1d (which does not have axis param), all methods have same signature as this method.

category.pattern: THE TENSORS RANKS AND TYPES MUST MATCH AND THEIR SIZES MUST MATCH IN ALL DIMENSIONS EXCEPT AXIS
category.template: The tensors ranks and types must match, and their sizes must match in all dimensions except axis.

category.pattern: CONCATENATES A LIST OF TF.TENSORS ALONG A GIVEN AXIS
category.template: Concatenates a list of tf.Tensors along a given axis.

category.pattern: APPLY BOOLEAN MASK TO TENSOR
category.template: Apply boolean mask to tensor.

category.pattern: TENSORFLOW.JS PROVIDES SEVERAL OPERATIONS TO SLICE OR EXTRACT PARTS OF A TENSOR OR JOIN MULTIPLE TENSORS TOGETHER
category.template: TensorFlow.js provides several operations to slice or extract parts of a tensor, or join multiple tensors together.

category.pattern: REMOVES DIMENSIONS OF SIZE 1 FROM THE SHAPE OF A TF.TENSOR
category.template: Removes dimensions of size 1 from the shape of a tf.Tensor.

category.pattern: ZERO-PAD THE START AND END OF DIMENSIONS [ 1 . . . M ] OF THE INPUT ACCORDING TO PADDINGS TO PRODUCE PADDED OF SHAPE PADDEDSHAPE
category.template: Zero-pad the start and end of dimensions [1, ..., M] of the input according to paddings to produce padded of shape paddedShape.

category.pattern: THIS OPERATION DIVIDES SPATIAL DIMENSIONS [ 1 . . . M ] OF THE INPUT INTO A GRID OF BLOCKS OF SHAPE BLOCKSHAPE AND INTERLEAVES THESE BLOCKS WITH THE BATCH DIMENSION ( 0 ) SUCH THAT IN THE OUTPUT THE SPATIAL DIMENSIONS [ 1 . . . M ] CORRESPOND TO THE POSITION WITHIN THE GRID AND THE BATCH DIMENSION COMBINES BOTH THE POSITION WITHIN A SPATIAL BLOCK AND THE ORIGINAL BATCH POSITION . PRIOR TO DIVISION INTO BLOCKS THE SPATIAL DIMENSIONS OF THE INPUT ARE OPTIONALLY ZERO PADDED ACCORDING TO PADDINGS . SEE BELOW FOR A PRECISE DESCRIPTION
category.template: This operation divides "spatial" dimensions [1, ..., M] of the input into a grid of blocks of shape blockShape, and interleaves these blocks with the "batch" dimension (0) such that in the output, the spatial dimensions [1, ..., M] correspond to the position within the grid, and the batch dimension combines both the position within a spatial block and the original batch position. Prior to division into blocks, the spatial dimensions of the input are optionally zero padded according to paddings. See below for a precise description.

category.pattern: COMPUTES THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN TWO LISTS OF NUMBERS
category.template: Computes the difference between two lists of numbers.

category.pattern: IF SHAPE IS 1 - D OR HIGHER THEN THE OPERATION RETURNS A TENSOR WITH SHAPE SHAPE FILLED WITH THE VALUES OF TENSOR . IN THIS CASE THE NUMBER OF ELEMENTS IMPLIED BY SHAPE MUST BE THE SAME AS THE NUMBER OF ELEMENTS IN TENSOR
category.template: If shape is 1-D or higher, then the operation returns a tensor with shape shape filled with the values of tensor. In this case, the number of elements implied by shape must be the same as the number of elements in tensor.

category.pattern: IF ONE COMPONENT OF SHAPE IS THE SPECIAL VALUE -1 THE SIZE OF THAT DIMENSION IS COMPUTED SO THAT THE TOTAL SIZE REMAINS CONSTANT . IN PARTICULAR A SHAPE OF [ -1 ] FLATTENS INTO 1 - D . AT MOST ONE COMPONENT OF SHAPE CAN BE -1
category.template: If one component of shape is the special value -1, the size of that dimension is computed so that the total size remains constant. In particular, a shape of [-1] flattens into 1-D. At most one component of shape can be -1.

category.pattern: GIVEN AN INPUT TENSOR RETURNS A NEW TENSOR WITH THE SAME VALUES AS THE INPUT TENSOR WITH SHAPE SHAPE
category.template: Given an input tensor, returns a new tensor with the same values as the input tensor with shape shape.

category.pattern: RESHAPES A TF.TENSOR TO A GIVEN SHAPE
category.template: Reshapes a tf.Tensor to a given shape.

category.pattern: ALSO AVAILABLE ARE STRICTER RANK-SPECIFIC METHODS WITH THE SAME SIGNATURE AS THIS METHOD THAT ASSERT THAT PADDINGS IS OF GIVEN LENGTH
category.template: Also available are stricter rank-specific methods with the same signature as this method that assert that paddings is of given length.

category.pattern: PADS A TF.TENSOR WITH A GIVEN VALUE AND PADDINGS
category.template: Pads a tf.Tensor with a given value and paddings.

category.pattern: THIS OPERATION IMPLEMENTS THE REFLECT AND SYMMETRIC MODES OF PAD
category.template: This operation implements the REFLECT and SYMMETRIC modes of pad.

category.pattern: PADS A TF.TENSOR USING MIRROR PADDING
category.template: Pads a tf.Tensor using mirror padding.

category.pattern: RETURNS A TF.TENSOR THAT HAS EXPANDED RANK BY INSERTING A DIMENSION INTO THE TENSOR S SHAPE
category.template: Returns a tf.Tensor that has expanded rank, by inserting a dimension into the tensor's shape.

category.pattern: REARRANGES DATA FROM DEPTH INTO BLOCKS OF SPATIAL DATA . MORE SPECIFICALLY THIS OP OUTPUTS A COPY OF THE INPUT TENSOR WHERE VALUES FROM THE DEPTH DIMENSION ARE MOVED IN SPATIAL BLOCKS TO THE HEIGHT AND WIDTH DIMENSIONS . THE ATTR BLOCKSIZE INDICATES THE INPUT BLOCK SIZE AND HOW THE DATA IS MOVED
category.template: Rearranges data from depth into blocks of spatial data. More specifically, this op outputs a copy of the input tensor where values from the depth dimension are moved in spatial blocks to the height and width dimensions. The attr blockSize indicates the input block size and how the data is moved.

category.pattern: CASTS A TF.TENSOR TO A NEW DTYPE
category.template: Casts a tf.Tensor to a new dtype.

category.pattern: THE TENSOR S SHAPE IS COMPARED TO THE BROADCAST SHAPE FROM END TO BEGINNING . ONES ARE PREPENDED TO THE TENSOR S SHAPE UNTIL IS HAS THE SAME LENGTH AS THE BROADCAST SHAPE . IF INPUT.SHAPE [ I ] = = SHAPE [ I ] THE ( I + 1 ) - TH AXIS IS ALREADY BROADCAST-COMPATIBLE . IF INPUT.SHAPE [ I ] = = 1 AND SHAPE [ I ] = = N THEN THE INPUT TENSOR IS TILED N TIMES ALONG THAT AXIS ( USING TF.TILE )
category.template: The tensor's shape is compared to the broadcast shape from end to beginning. Ones are prepended to the tensor's shape until is has the same length as the broadcast shape. If input.shape[i]==shape[i], the (i+1)-th axis is already broadcast-compatible. If input.shape[i]==1 and shape[i]==N, then the input tensor is tiled N times along that axis (using tf.tile).

category.pattern: BROADCAST AN ARRAY TO A COMPATIBLE SHAPE NUMPY-STYLE
category.template: Broadcast an array to a compatible shape NumPy-style.

category.pattern: THIS FUNCTION RETURNS THE SHAPE OF THE RESULT OF AN OPERATION BETWEEN TWO TENSORS OF SIZE S0 AND S1 PERFORMED WITH BROADCAST
category.template: This function returns the shape of the result of an operation between two tensors of size s0 and s1 performed with broadcast.

category.pattern: COMPUTE R0 THE BROADCASTED SHAPE AS A TENSOR . S0 S1 AND R0 ARE ALL INTEGER VECTORS
category.template: compute r0, the broadcasted shape as a tensor. s0, s1 and r0 are all integer vectors.

category.pattern: RETURN THE SHAPE OF S0 OP S1 WITH BROADCAST
category.template: Return the shape of s0 op s1 with broadcast.

category.pattern: THIS OPERATION RESHAPES THE BATCH DIMENSION 0 INTO M + 1 DIMENSIONS OF SHAPE BLOCKSHAPE + [ BATCH ] INTERLEAVES THESE BLOCKS BACK INTO THE GRID DEFINED BY THE SPATIAL DIMENSIONS [ 1 . . . M ] TO OBTAIN A RESULT WITH THE SAME RANK AS THE INPUT . THE SPATIAL DIMENSIONS OF THIS INTERMEDIATE RESULT ARE THEN OPTIONALLY CROPPED ACCORDING TO CROPS TO PRODUCE THE OUTPUT . THIS IS THE REVERSE OF TF.SPACETOBATCHND ( ) . SEE BELOW FOR A PRECISE DESCRIPTION
category.template: This operation reshapes the "batch" dimension 0 into M + 1 dimensions of shape blockShape + [batch], interleaves these blocks back into the grid defined by the spatial dimensions [1, ..., M], to obtain a result with the same rank as the input. The spatial dimensions of this intermediate result are then optionally cropped according to crops to produce the output. This is the reverse of tf.spaceToBatchND(). See below for a precise description.

category.pattern: THIS SECTION DESCRIBES SOME COMMON TENSOR TRANSFORMATIONS FOR RESHAPING AND TYPE-CASTING
category.template: This section describes some common Tensor transformations for reshaping and type-casting.

category.pattern: CREATES AN IMMUTABLE TF.TENSOR OBJECT FROM THE BUFFER
category.template: Creates an immutable tf.Tensor object from the buffer.

category.pattern: RETURNS THE VALUE IN THE BUFFER AT THE PROVIDED LOCATION
category.template: Returns the value in the buffer at the provided location.

category.pattern: SETS A VALUE IN THE BUFFER AT A GIVEN LOCATION
category.template: Sets a value in the buffer at a given location.

category.pattern: SEE TF.BUFFER ( ) FOR CREATING A TENSOR BUFFER
category.template: See tf.buffer() for creating a tensor buffer.

category.pattern: A MUTABLE OBJECT SIMILAR TO TF.TENSOR THAT ALLOWS USERS TO SET VALUES AT LOCATIONS BEFORE CONVERTING TO AN IMMUTABLE TF.TENSOR
category.template: A mutable object, similar to tf.Tensor, that allows users to set values at locations before converting to an immutable tf.Tensor.

category.pattern: ASSIGN A NEW TF.TENSOR TO THIS VARIABLE . THE NEW TF.TENSOR MUST HAVE THE SAME SHAPE AND DTYPE AS THE OLD TF.TENSOR
category.template: Assign a new tf.Tensor to this variable. The new tf.Tensor must have the same shape and dtype as the old tf.Tensor.

category.pattern: A MUTABLE TF.TENSOR USEFUL FOR PERSISTING STATE E.G . FOR TRAINING
category.template: A mutable tf.Tensor, useful for persisting state, e.g. for training.

category.pattern: RETURNS A HUMAN-READABLE DESCRIPTION OF THE TENSOR . USEFUL FOR LOGGING
category.template: Returns a human-readable description of the tensor. Useful for logging.

category.pattern: RETURNS A COPY OF THE TENSOR . SEE TF.CLONE ( ) FOR DETAILS
category.template: Returns a copy of the tensor. See tf.clone() for details.

category.pattern: PRINTS THE TF.TENSOR . SEE TF.PRINT ( ) FOR DETAILS
category.template: Prints the tf.Tensor. See tf.print() for details.

category.pattern: DISPOSES TF.TENSOR FROM MEMORY
category.template: Disposes tf.Tensor from memory.

category.pattern: SYNCHRONOUSLY DOWNLOADS THE VALUES FROM THE TF.TENSOR . THIS BLOCKS THE UI THREAD UNTIL THE VALUES ARE READY WHICH CAN CAUSE PERFORMANCE ISSUES
category.template: Synchronously downloads the values from the tf.Tensor. This blocks the UI thread until the values are ready, which can cause performance issues.

category.pattern: FOR WEBGPU BACKEND THE DATA WILL BE STORED ON A BUFFER . THERE IS NO PARAMETER SO CAN NOT USE AN USER DEFINED SIZE TO CREATE THE BUFFER
category.template: For WebGPU backend, the data will be stored on a buffer. There is no parameter, so can not use an user defined size to create the buffer.

category.pattern: FOR WEBGL BACKEND THE DATA WILL BE STORED ON A DENSELY PACKED TEXTURE . THIS MEANS THAT THE TEXTURE WILL USE THE RGBA CHANNELS TO STORE VALUE
category.template: For WebGL backend, the data will be stored on a densely packed texture. This means that the texture will use the RGBA channels to store value.

category.pattern: COPY THE TENSOR S DATA TO A NEW GPU RESOURCE . COMPARING TO THE DATASYNC ( ) AND DATA ( ) THIS METHOD PREVENTS DATA FROM BEING DOWNLOADED TO CPU
category.template: Copy the tensor's data to a new GPU resource. Comparing to the dataSync() and data(), this method prevents data from being downloaded to CPU.

category.pattern: ASYNCHRONOUSLY DOWNLOADS THE VALUES FROM THE TF.TENSOR . RETURNS A PROMISE OF TYPEDARRAY THAT RESOLVES WHEN THE COMPUTATION HAS FINISHED
category.template: Asynchronously downloads the values from the tf.Tensor. Returns a promise of TypedArray that resolves when the computation has finished.

category.pattern: RETURNS THE TENSOR DATA AS A NESTED ARRAY . THE TRANSFER OF DATA IS DONE SYNCHRONOUSLY
category.template: Returns the tensor data as a nested array. The transfer of data is done synchronously.

category.pattern: RETURNS THE TENSOR DATA AS A NESTED ARRAY . THE TRANSFER OF DATA IS DONE ASYNCHRONOUSLY
category.template: Returns the tensor data as a nested array. The transfer of data is done asynchronously.

category.pattern: RETURNS A TF.TENSORBUFFER THAT HOLDS THE UNDERLYING DATA
category.template: Returns a tf.TensorBuffer that holds the underlying data.

category.pattern: RETURNS A PROMISE OF TF.TENSORBUFFER THAT HOLDS THE UNDERLYING DATA
category.template: Returns a promise of tf.TensorBuffer that holds the underlying data.

category.pattern: SEE TF.TENSOR ( ) FOR DETAILS ON HOW TO CREATE A TF.TENSOR
category.template: See tf.tensor() for details on how to create a tf.Tensor.

category.pattern: FOR PERFORMANCE REASONS FUNCTIONS THAT CREATE TENSORS DO NOT NECESSARILY PERFORM A COPY OF THE DATA PASSED TO THEM ( E.G . IF THE DATA IS PASSED AS A FLOAT32ARRAY ) AND CHANGES TO THE DATA WILL CHANGE THE TENSOR . THIS IS NOT A FEATURE AND IS NOT SUPPORTED . TO AVOID THIS BEHAVIOR USE THE TENSOR BEFORE CHANGING THE INPUT DATA OR CREATE A COPY WITH COPY = TF.ADD ( YOURTENSOR 0 )
category.template: For performance reasons, functions that create tensors do not necessarily perform a copy of the data passed to them (e.g. if the data is passed as a Float32Array), and changes to the data will change the tensor. This is not a feature and is not supported. To avoid this behavior, use the tensor before changing the input data or create a copy with copy = tf.add(yourTensor, 0).

category.pattern: A TF.TENSOR OBJECT REPRESENTS AN IMMUTABLE MULTIDIMENSIONAL ARRAY OF NUMBERS THAT HAS A SHAPE AND A DATA TYPE
category.template: A tf.Tensor object represents an immutable, multidimensional array of numbers that has a shape and a data type.

category.pattern: THIS SECTION SHOWS THE MAIN TENSOR RELATED CLASSES IN TENSORFLOW.JS AND THE METHODS WE EXPOSE ON THEM
category.template: This section shows the main Tensor related classes in TensorFlow.js and the methods we expose on them.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH ALL ELEMENTS SET TO 0 WITH THE SAME SHAPE AS THE GIVEN TENSOR
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with all elements set to 0 with the same shape as the given tensor.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH ALL ELEMENTS SET TO 0
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with all elements set to 0.

category.pattern: CREATES A NEW VARIABLE WITH THE PROVIDED INITIAL VALUE
category.template: Creates a new variable with the provided initial value.

category.pattern: THE GENERATED VALUES FOLLOW A NORMAL DISTRIBUTION WITH SPECIFIED MEAN AND STANDARD DEVIATION EXCEPT THAT VALUES WHOSE MAGNITUDE IS MORE THAN 2 STANDARD DEVIATIONS FROM THE MEAN ARE DROPPED AND RE-PICKED
category.template: The generated values follow a normal distribution with specified mean and standard deviation, except that values whose magnitude is more than 2 standard deviations from the mean are dropped and re-picked.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH VALUES SAMPLED FROM A TRUNCATED NORMAL DISTRIBUTION
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with values sampled from a truncated normal distribution.

category.pattern: IF THE INPUT IS REAL IT SIMPLY MAKES A CLONE
category.template: If the input is real, it simply makes a clone.

category.pattern: GIVEN A TENSOR INPUT THIS OPERATION RETURNS A TENSOR OF TYPE FLOAT THAT IS THE REAL PART OF EACH ELEMENT IN INPUT CONSIDERED AS A COMPLEX NUMBER
category.template: Given a tensor input, this operation returns a tensor of type float that is the real part of each element in input considered as a complex number.

category.pattern: RETURNS THE REAL PART OF A COMPLEX ( OR REAL ) TENSOR
category.template: Returns the real part of a complex (or real) tensor.

category.pattern: CREATES A NEW TF.TENSOR1D FILLED WITH THE NUMBERS IN THE RANGE PROVIDED
category.template: Creates a new tf.Tensor1D filled with the numbers in the range provided.

category.pattern: PRINTS INFORMATION ABOUT THE TF.TENSOR INCLUDING ITS DATA
category.template: Prints information about the tf.Tensor including its data.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH ALL ELEMENTS SET TO 1 WITH THE SAME SHAPE AS THE GIVEN TENSOR
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with all elements set to 1 with the same shape as the given tensor.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH ALL ELEMENTS SET TO 1
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with all elements set to 1.

category.pattern: CREATES A ONE-HOT TF.TENSOR . THE LOCATIONS REPRESENTED BY INDICES TAKE VALUE ONVALUE ( DEFAULTS TO 1 ) WHILE ALL OTHER LOCATIONS TAKE VALUE OFFVALUE ( DEFAULTS TO 0 ) . IF INDICES IS RANK R THE OUTPUT HAS RANK R + 1 WITH THE LAST AXIS OF SIZE DEPTH . INDICES USED TO ENCODE PREDICTION CLASS MUST START FROM 0 . FOR EXAMPLE IF YOU HAVE 3 CLASSES OF DATA CLASS 1 SHOULD BE ENCODED AS 0 CLASS 2 SHOULD BE 1 AND CLASS 3 SHOULD BE 2
category.template: Creates a one-hot tf.Tensor. The locations represented by indices take value onValue (defaults to 1), while all other locations take value offValue (defaults to 0). If indices is rank R, the output has rank R+1 with the last axis of size depth. indices used to encode prediction class must start from 0. For example, if you have 3 classes of data, class 1 should be encoded as 0, class 2 should be 1, and class 3 should be 2.

category.pattern: RETURN AN EVENLY SPACED SEQUENCE OF NUMBERS OVER THE GIVEN INTERVAL
category.template: Return an evenly spaced sequence of numbers over the given interval.

category.pattern: GIVEN A TENSOR INPUT THIS OPERATION RETURNS A TENSOR OF TYPE FLOAT THAT IS THE IMAGINARY PART OF EACH ELEMENT IN INPUT CONSIDERED AS A COMPLEX NUMBER . IF INPUT IS REAL A TENSOR OF ALL ZEROS IS RETURNED
category.template: Given a tensor input, this operation returns a tensor of type float that is the imaginary part of each element in input considered as a complex number. If input is real, a tensor of all zeros is returned.

category.pattern: RETURNS THE IMAGINARY PART OF A COMPLEX ( OR REAL ) TENSOR
category.template: Returns the imaginary part of a complex (or real) tensor.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR FILLED WITH A SCALAR VALUE
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor filled with a scalar value.

category.pattern: CREATE AN IDENTITY MATRIX
category.template: Create an identity matrix.

category.pattern: GIVEN A DIAGONAL THIS OPERATION RETURNS A TENSOR WITH THE DIAGONAL AND EVERYTHING ELSE PADDED WITH ZEROS
category.template: Given a diagonal, this operation returns a tensor with the diagonal and everything else padded with zeros.

category.pattern: RETURNS A DIAGONAL TENSOR WITH A GIVEN DIAGONAL VALUES
category.template: Returns a diagonal tensor with a given diagonal values.

category.pattern: THE INPUT TENSORS REAL AND IMAG MUST HAVE THE SAME SHAPE
category.template: The input tensors real and imag must have the same shape.

category.pattern: GIVEN A TENSOR REAL REPRESENTING THE REAL PART OF A COMPLEX NUMBER AND A TENSOR IMAG REPRESENTING THE IMAGINARY PART OF A COMPLEX NUMBER THIS OPERATION RETURNS COMPLEX NUMBERS ELEMENTWISE OF THE FORM [ R0 I0 R1 I1 ] WHERE R REPRESENTS THE REAL PART AND I REPRESENTS THE IMAG PART
category.template: Given a tensor real representing the real part of a complex number, and a tensor imag representing the imaginary part of a complex number, this operation returns complex numbers elementwise of the form [r0, i0, r1, i1], where r represents the real part and i represents the imag part.

category.pattern: CONVERTS TWO REAL NUMBERS TO A COMPLEX NUMBER
category.template: Converts two real numbers to a complex number.

category.pattern: CREATES A NEW TENSOR WITH THE SAME VALUES AND SHAPE AS THE SPECIFIED TENSOR
category.template: Creates a new tensor with the same values and shape as the specified tensor.

category.pattern: WHEN DONE CALL BUFFER.TOTENSOR ( ) TO GET AN IMMUTABLE TF.TENSOR WITH THOSE VALUES
category.template: When done, call buffer.toTensor() to get an immutable tf.Tensor with those values.

category.pattern: THE VALUES ARE STORED IN CPU AS TYPEDARRAY . FILL THE BUFFER USING BUFFER.SET ( ) OR BY MODIFYING DIRECTLY BUFFER.VALUES
category.template: The values are stored in CPU as TypedArray. Fill the buffer using buffer.set(), or by modifying directly buffer.values.

category.pattern: CREATES AN EMPTY TF.TENSORBUFFER WITH THE SPECIFIED SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates an empty tf.TensorBuffer with the specified shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR6D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor6d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-6 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-6 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR5D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor5d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-5 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-5 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR4D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor4d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-4 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-4 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR3D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor3d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-3 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-3 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR2D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor2d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-2 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-2 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.TENSOR1D ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.tensor1d() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-1 TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-1 tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: THE SAME FUNCTIONALITY CAN BE ACHIEVED WITH TF.TENSOR ( ) BUT IN GENERAL WE RECOMMEND USING TF.SCALAR ( ) AS IT MAKES THE CODE MORE READABLE
category.template: The same functionality can be achieved with tf.tensor(), but in general we recommend using tf.scalar() as it makes the code more readable.

category.pattern: CREATES RANK-0 TF.TENSOR ( SCALAR ) WITH THE PROVIDED VALUE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates rank-0 tf.Tensor (scalar) with the provided value and dtype.

category.pattern: CREATES A TF.TENSOR WITH THE PROVIDED VALUES SHAPE AND DTYPE
category.template: Creates a tf.Tensor with the provided values, shape and dtype.

category.pattern: WE HAVE UTILITY FUNCTIONS FOR COMMON CASES LIKE SCALAR 1D 2D 3D AND 4D TENSORS AS WELL A NUMBER OF FUNCTIONS TO INITIALIZE TENSORS IN WAYS USEFUL FOR MACHINE LEARNING
category.template: We have utility functions for common cases like Scalar, 1D, 2D, 3D and 4D tensors, as well a number of functions to initialize tensors in ways useful for machine learning.

category.pattern: TENSORS ARE THE CORE DATASTRUCTURE OF TENSORFLOW.JS THEY ARE A GENERALIZATION OF VECTORS AND MATRICES TO POTENTIALLY HIGHER DIMENSIONS
category.template: Tensors are the core datastructure of TensorFlow.js They are a generalization of vectors and matrices to potentially higher dimensions.

category.pattern: BOT LIBRE S AIML 2.0 SUPPORT IS IMPLEMENTED BY TRANSLATING AIML INTO SELF . SELF 2.0 PROVIDES MANY NEW EXTENSIONS TO SUPPORT THE AIML 2.0 FEATURE SET AS WELL AS A LOT MORE FUNCTIONALITY THAN IS NOT AVAILABLE IN AIML
category.template: Bot Libre's AIML 2.0 support is implemented by translating AIML into Self. Self 2.0 provides many new extensions to support the AIML 2.0 feature set, as well as a lot more functionality than is not available in AIML.

category.pattern: THE BOT WILL NOT RUN THE AIML SCRIPT AS A SCRIPT IT WILL DECIDE FOR ITSELF WHEN TO USE THE RESPONSE USING A HEURISTIC ALGORITHM . THE BOT WILL CHOOSE ITS RESPONSE BASED ON HOW WELL THE QUESTION MATCHES THE RESPONSES QUESTION THE RESPONSES CORRECTNESS AND THE CONTEXT . EVEN WITHOUT A * IN A PATTERN IT STILL MAY BE MATCHED TO A SIMILAR QUESTION IF IT IS THE BEST MATCH AVAILABLE . THIS FREES YOU FROM HAVING TO WRITE A PATTERN FOR EVERY POSSIBLE PHRASE BY JUST LETTING THE BOT FIGURE IT OUT
category.template: The bot will not run the AIML script as a script, it will decide for itself when to use the response using a heuristic algorithm. The bot will choose its response based on how well the question matches the responses question, the responses correctness, and the context. Even without a * in a pattern it still may be matched to a similar question, if it is the best match available. This frees you from having to write a pattern for every possible phrase, by just letting the bot figure it out.

category.pattern: IMPORTING AIML AS A CHAT LOG ALLOWS THE AIML CATEGORIES TO BE INTEGRATED INTO THE BOT S KNOWLEDGEBASE . THE PATTERN / TEMPLATE CATEGORIES FROM THE AIML FILE WILL BE MERGED ALONG WITH THE BOT S OTHER QUESTION / RESPONSE PAIRS THAT IT HAS LEARNED THROUGH TRAINING CONVERSATION CORRECTION OR IMPORTING
category.template: Importing AIML as a chat log allows the AIML categories to be integrated into the bot's knowledgebase. The pattern/template categories from the AIML file will be merged along with the bot's other question/response pairs that it has learned through training, conversation, correction, or importing.

category.pattern: WHEN YOU IMPORT AN AIML FILE IT WILL BE CONVERTED TO SELF CODE AND STORED IN YOUR BOT S BRAIN ALONG WITH ALL OF ITS OTHER INFORMATION . THE SELF SYNTAX FOR AIML IS A HYBRID SYNTAX THAT USES AIML TERMINOLOGY BUT WITH THE SELF SCRIPTING STRUCTURE . SELF IS AN OBJECT ORIENTED LANGUAGE MODELED AFTER JAVASCRIPT . SELF IS VERY DIFFERENT THAN AIML BUT CAN PROCESS ANY AIML CODE SIMILAR TO ANY OTHER AIML INTERPRETER . AIML IMPORTED AS A PROGRAM SCRIPT WILL BE EXECUTED SIMILAR TO ANY OTHER AIML INTERPRETER
category.template: When you import an AIML file, it will be converted to Self code, and stored in your bot's brain along with all of its other information. The Self syntax for AIML is a hybrid syntax that uses AIML terminology, but with the Self scripting structure. Self is an object oriented language modeled after JavaScript. Self is very different than AIML, but can process any AIML code similar to any other AIML interpreter. AIML imported as a program script will be executed similar to any other AIML interpreter.

category.pattern: IMPORTING AIML AS A PROGRAM SCRIPT IS DONE FROM THE SCRIPTS PAGE . YOU CAN IMPORT AND ORDER THE SCRIPT WITH RESPECT TO YOUR OTHER SCRIPTS FILES . SCRIPTS CAN BE DEFINED IN EITHER AIML OR SELF
category.template: Importing AIML as a program script is done from the Scripts page. You can import and order the script with respect to your other scripts files. Scripts can be defined in either AIML or Self.

category.pattern: FOR REFERENCE HERE IS THE COMPLETE SET OF AIML TEMPLATE TAGS
category.template: For reference, here is the complete set of AIML template tags.

category.pattern: FOR REFERENCE HERE IS THE COMPLETE SET OF AIML PATTERNS TAGS AND CHARACTERS
category.template: For reference, here is the complete set of AIML patterns tags and characters.

category.pattern: FOR REFERENCE HERE IS THE COMPLETE SET OF AIML CATEGORY TAGS
category.template: For reference, here is the complete set of AIML category tags.

category.pattern: BOT LIBRE S WEB AND MOBILE SDKS DO NOT CURRENTLY SUPPORT OOB TAGS SO OOB TAGS ARE NOT CURRENTLY SUPPORTED
category.template: Bot Libre's web and mobile SDKs do not currently support oob tags, so oob tags are not currently supported.

category.pattern: OUT OF BAND TAGS LET YOU PASS TAGS OR COMMANDS TO THE BOT CLIENT . THE CLIENT COULD MAKE USE OF THE TAGS TO CONTROL ITS AVATAR OR EXECUTE SERVICES ON A PHONE OR MOBILE DEVICE
category.template: Out of band tags let you pass tags or commands to the bot client. The client could make use of the tags to control its avatar, or execute services on a phone or mobile device.

category.pattern: AIML 2.0 DEFINES THE PANNOUS SERVICE AS BEING THE DEFAULT FOR ANY SRAIX REQUEST . PANNOUS IS A VIRTUAL ASSISTANT SERVICE THAT CAN ANSWER A WIDE VARIETY OF QUESTIONS SUCH AS WEATHER DEFINITIONS MATH AND MUCH MORE
category.template: AIML 2.0 defines the Pannous service as being the default for any sraix request. Pannous is a virtual assistant service that can answer a wide variety of questions, such as weather, definitions, math, and much more.

category.pattern: SRAIX IS A VERY COOL FEATURE BUT NOT VERY USEFUL ON ITS OWN AS YOU NEED OTHER BOTS TO TALK TO AND SERVICES TO MAKE USE OF . UNFORTUNATELY AIML ONLY DEFINES THE TAG IT DOES NOT DEFINE A STANDARD WEB API FOR REQUESTS OR DEFINE A STANDARD SET OF SERVICES . FORTUNATELY PROGRAM AB THE AIML 2.0 REFERENCE IMPLEMENTATION DOES DEFINE A SRAIX WEB API . BOT LIBRE SUPPORTS BOTH CALLING THIS API AND SUPPORTS THIS API ON OUR SERVERS . SO YOU CAN NOW SRAIX ANY PROGRAM AB WEB API COMPATIBLE BOT OR SERVICE AND ANY PROGRAM AB WEB API COMPATIBLE BOT OR SERVICE CAN REQUEST ANY BOT LIBRE BOT
category.template: sraix is a very cool feature, but not very useful on its own, as you need other bots to talk to, and services to make use of. Unfortunately AIML only defines the tag, it does not define a standard web API for requests, or define a standard set of services. Fortunately Program AB the AIML 2.0 reference implementation does define a sraix web API. Bot Libre supports both calling this API, and supports this API on our servers. So you can now sraix any Program AB web API compatible bot or service, and any Program AB web API compatible bot or service can request any Bot Libre bot.

category.pattern: THE NEW < SRAIX > TAGS ALLOW THE BOT PERFORM A REMOTE REQUEST OF ANOTHER BOT OR SERVICE . SRAIX IS SIMILAR TO THE SRAI TAG THAT RECURSIVELY EVALUATES THE ELEMENT TEXT AS IF IT WERE A QUESTION . HOWEVER SRAIX DOES NOT HAVE THE BOT EVALUATE THE QUESTION LOCALLY BUT INSTEAD ASKS ANOTHER BOT OR SERVICE THE QUESTION . THIS IS PROBABLY THE COOLEST NEW FEATURE OF AIML 2.0 AND OPENS UP THE WHOLE CHAT BOT WORLD . BOTS CAN NOW TALK TO OTHER BOTS AND FIND THINGS THROUGH WEB SERVICES
category.template: The new tags allow the bot perform a remote request of another bot or service. sraix is similar to the srai tag that recursively evaluates the element text as if it were a question. However, sraix does not have the bot evaluate the question locally, but instead asks another bot or service the question. This is probably the coolest new feature of AIML 2.0, and opens up the whole chat bot world. Bots can now talk to other bots, and find things through web services.

category.pattern: THE NEW < LEARN > AND < LEARNF > TAGS ALLOW THE BOT TO LEARN NEW RESPONSE . THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE TWO IS THAT FOR LEARN THE NEW RESPONSE IS ONLY REMEMBERED FOR THE CONVERSATION AND FOR LEARNF THE NEW RESPONSE WILL BE REMEMBERED PERSISTENTLY . HOWEVER IN BOT LIBRE EVERYTHING IS ALWAYS PERSISTENT SO BOTH TAG WILL LEARN PERSISTENTLY
category.template: The new and tags allow the bot to learn new response. The difference between the two is that for learn the new response is only remembered for the conversation, and for learnf the new response will be remembered persistently. However, in Bot Libre everything is always persistent, so both tag will learn persistently.

category.pattern: CONDITIONS NOW ALLOWS VALUES TO USE PATTERNS . THIS MAKES IT EASY TO DEFINE DEFAULT CASES
category.template: Conditions now allows values to use patterns. This makes it easy to define default cases.

category.pattern: BOT LIBRE EXTENDS THE MAP OPERATION TO ALSO ALLOW SETTING THE MAP VALUE . THIS WILL SET THE VALUE OF A RELATIONSHIP ON THE KNOWLEDGE OBJECT
category.template: Bot Libre extends the map operation to also allow setting the map value. This will set the value of a relationship on the knowledge object.

category.pattern: IN BOT LIBRE MAPS ARE NOT STORED IN FILES LIKE OTHER AIML IMPLEMENTATIONS . AIML IS A TEXT PROCESSING LANGUAGE BUT BOT LIBRE IS OBJECT OR KNOWLEDGE ORIENTED . EACH BOT HAS ITS OWN OBJECT ORIENTED KNOWLEDGE BASE THAT STORES ALL OF ITS RESPONSES AND KNOWLEDGE . EACH WORD IS REPRESENTED BY A KNOWLEDGE OBJECT IN THE BOT S KNOWLEDGE BASE . KNOWLEDGE OBJECTS CAN HAVE RELATIONSHIPS TO ANY OTHER KNOWLEDGE OBJECTS . THE MAP OPERATION IN BOT LIBRE BASICALLY LOOKS UP THE RELATIONSHIP ON THE KNOWLEDGE OBJECT
category.template: In Bot Libre maps are not stored in files like other AIML implementations. AIML is a text processing language, but Bot Libre is object, or knowledge oriented. Each bot has its own object oriented knowledge base that stores all of its responses, and knowledge. Each word is represented by a knowledge object in the bot's knowledge base. Knowledge objects can have relationships to any other knowledge objects. The map operation in Bot Libre basically looks up the relationship on the knowledge object.

category.pattern: THE NEW < MAP > TAG CAN BE USED TO LOOKUP THE VALUE FOR A WORD IN A PREDEFINED MAPPING . THIS ALLOWS FOR EASY MAPPING BETWEEN VALUES . WHAT IS THE CAPITAL OF COUNTRY THE CAPITAL OF IN .
category.template:
The new tag can be used to lookup the value for a word in a predefined mapping. This allows for easy mapping between values.
what is the capital of country The capital of in .

category.pattern: AIML 2.0 ADDS MANY NEW TAGS AND SOME NEW SEMANTICS THAT LET YOU DO SOME PRETTY POWERFUL THINGS
category.template: AIML 2.0 adds many new tags, and some new semantics that let you do some pretty powerful things.

category.pattern: TAGS SUCH AS < BOT > CAN NOW BE USED IN PATTERNS . AIML 2.0 ONLY REQUIRES SOME TAGS BE USABLE IN PATTERNS BUT BOT LIBRE ALLOWS MOST TAGS TO BE USED . USING TAGS IN PATTERNS LETS YOU DEFINE SOME PRETTY CREATIVE PATTERNS . YES THAT S MY NAME . I AM THAT IS MY AGE TOO . YOU ARE REPEATING YOURSELF . PLEASE DON T REPEAT ME
category.template:
Tags such as can now be used in patterns. AIML 2.0 only requires some tags be usable in patterns, but Bot Libre allows most tags to be used. Using tags in patterns lets you define some pretty creative patterns.
Yes, that's my name.
I am That is my age too.
You are repeating yourself.
Please don't repeat me.

category.pattern: THE SET OPERATION IN BOT LIBRE BASICALLY CHECKS IF THE TYPE OF THE WORD S KNOWLEDGE OBJECT MATCHES THE SET VALUE . THIS ALLOWS FOR A KNOWLEDGE OBJECT TO BE ADDED TO ANY SET THROUGH SETTING ITS #INSTANTIATION RELATIONSHIP . THIS CAN BE DONE USING SELF SCRIPTS THE AIML MAP TAG AND IS DONE AUTOMATICALLY FOR NUMBERS BASIC TYPES AND WORDS OR DATA LOADED FROM WIKTIONARY WIKIDATA OR FREEBASE
category.template: The set operation in Bot Libre basically checks if the type of the word's knowledge object matches the set value. This allows for a knowledge object to be added to any set through setting its #instantiation relationship. This can be done using Self scripts, the AIML map tag, and is done automatically for numbers, basic types, and words or data loaded from Wiktionary, Wikidata, or Freebase.

category.pattern: IN BOT LIBRE SETS ARE NOT STORED IN FILES LIKE OTHER AIML IMPLEMENTATIONS . AIML IS A TEXT PROCESSING LANGUAGE BUT BOT LIBRE IS OBJECT OR KNOWLEDGE ORIENTED . EACH BOT HAS ITS OWN OBJECT ORIENTED KNOWLEDGE BASE THAT STORES ALL OF ITS RESPONSES AND KNOWLEDGE . EACH WORD IS REPRESENTED BY A MEANING KNOWLEDGE OBJECT IN THE BOT S KNOWLEDGE BASE . KNOWLEDGE OBJECTS CAN HAVE RELATIONSHIPS TO ANY OTHER KNOWLEDGE OBJECTS INCLUDING THEIR CLASSIFICATION TYPES . A WORD S MEANING IS DEFINED THROUGH THE #MEANING RELATIONSHIP AND A KNOWLEDGE OBJECT S TYPE IS DEFINED THROUGH THE #INSTANTIATION RELATIONSHIP
category.template: In Bot Libre sets are not stored in files like other AIML implementations. AIML is a text processing language, but Bot Libre is object, or knowledge oriented. Each bot has its own object oriented knowledge base that stores all of its responses, and knowledge. Each word is represented by a meaning knowledge object in the bot's knowledge base. Knowledge objects can have relationships to any other knowledge objects, including their classification types. A word's meaning is defined through the #meaning relationship, and a knowledge object's type is defined through the #instantiation relationship.

category.pattern: THE NEW $ PATTERN MARKER CAN BE USED TO MAKE A PATTERN WORD MATCH HIGHEST PRIORITY . THE MAIN PURPOSE OF THIS IS TO ALLOW PATTERNS TO TAKE PRIORITY OVER _ AND # WILDCARDS . _ AND # HAVE ODD SEMANTICS AND SHOULD NORMALLY BE AVOIDED AS THEY CAN EASILY LEAD TO LOOPS AND BLOCK OTHER PATTERNS . _ AND # CAN BE USEFUL FOR THINGS LIKE PROFANITY FILTERS : # SEX # I M NOT THAT KIND OF BOT . $ WHAT IS YOUR SEX I AM FEMALE
category.template:
The new $ pattern marker can be used to make a pattern word match highest priority. The main purpose of this is to allow patterns to take priority over _ and # wildcards. _ and # have odd semantics and should normally be avoided as they can easily lead to loops and block other patterns. _ and # can be useful for things like profanity filters:
# sex # I'm not that kind of bot.
$what is your sex I am female.

category.pattern: PATTERNS IN AIML ARE NORMALLY DEFINED AS ALL UPPERCASE BUT BOT LIBRE AUTOMATICALLY IGNORES CASE SO PATTERNS CAN BE DEFINED AS LOWERCASE OR MIXED . BOT LIBRE ALSO ALLOWS FOR SPECIAL CHARACTERS IN PATTERNS SUCH AS + % ? ETC
category.template: Patterns in AIML are normally defined as all uppercase, but Bot Libre automatically ignores case, so patterns can be defined as lowercase or mixed. Bot Libre also allows for special characters in patterns such as +, %, ?, etc.

category.pattern: AIML 2.0 ADDS NEW WILDCARDS SPECIAL CHARACTERS AND NOW ALLOWS THE USAGE OF SOME TAGS INSIDE PATTERNS
category.template: AIML 2.0 adds new wildcards, special characters, and now allows the usage of some tags inside patterns.

category.pattern: HERE IS THE LIST OF NEW AIML 2.0 FEATURES
category.template: Here is the list of new AIML 2.0 features.

category.pattern: AIML 2.0 DEFINES MANY NEW TEMPLATE TAGS AS WELL AS NOW ALLOWING SOME TAGS TO BE USED IN PATTERNS . AIML 2.0 ALSO ADDS NEW PATTERN WILDCARDS AND SOME DIFFERENT ELEMENT USAGES
category.template: AIML 2.0 defines many new template tags, as well as now allowing some tags to be used in patterns. AIML 2.0 also adds new pattern wildcards, and some different element usages.

category.pattern: HERE IS A SIMPLE HELLO WORLD AIML EXAMPLE : HELLO WORLD HELLO TO YOU TOO THIS CODE WILL MAKE YOUR BOT RESPOND WITH HELLO TO YOU TOO TO THE QUESTION HELLO WORLD
category.template:
Here is a simple "Hello World" AIML example:
HELLO WORLD Hello to you too
This code will make your bot respond with "Hello to you too" to the question "Hello World".

category.pattern: HERE IS A SIMPLE HELLO WORLD AIML EXAMPLE : HELLO WORLD HELLO TO YOU TOO THIS CODE WILL MAKE YOUR BOT RESPOND WITH HELLO TO YOU TOO TO THE QUESTION HELLO WORLD
category.template:
Here is a simple "Hello World" AIML example:
HELLO WORLD Hello to you too
This code will make your bot respond with "Hello to you too" to the question "Hello World".

category.pattern: BOT LIBRE NOW SUPPORTS THE AIML 2.0 DRAFT SPECIFICATION . AIML 2.0 IS THE SECOND RELEASE OF A STANDARD XML SPECIFICATION DESIGNED FOR SCRIPTING CHAT BOT RESPONSES . THE AIML 2.0 DRAFT WAS RELEASED IN 2013 AND LAST UPDATED IN 2014 . AIML IS SUPPORTED BY MANY DIFFERENT CHAT BOT PROGRAMS AND HOSTING SERVICES . BOT LIBRE SUPPORTS ALL OF THE AIML 2.0 DRAFT TAGS AND A FEW COMMON EXTENSIONS
category.template:
Bot Libre now supports the AIML 2.0 draft specification.
AIML 2.0 is the second release of a standard XML specification designed for scripting chat bot responses. The AIML 2.0 draft was released in 2013, and last updated in 2014. AIML is supported by many different chat bot programs and hosting services. Bot Libre supports all of the AIML 2.0 draft tags and a few common extensions.

category.pattern: CERTAIN INTENTS REQUIRE A RESULT . FOR SCANNER RESULTS USE THE REQUEST CODE & #34 ; 3 & #34 ; FOR VIDEO / CAMERA RESULTS USE THE REQUEST CODE & #34 ; 2 & #34 ;
category.template: Certain intents require a result. For Scanner results, use the request code "3", for Video/Camera results, use the request code "2".

category.pattern: USING GENERIC ARGUMENTS YOU CAN CREATE AND CUSTOMIZE YOUR OWN COMMANDS FOR YOUR BOT . REFER TO THE GENERIC INTENT COMMANDS SCRIPT FOR SOME EXAMPLES AND IDEAS IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO USE THE SPECIFIC-TYPE COMMANDS LISTED ABOVE
category.template: Using generic arguments, you can create and customize your own commands for your bot. Refer to the Generic Intent Commands script for some examples and ideas, if you do not wish to use the specific-type commands listed above.

category.pattern: WITH THESE COMMANDS YOUR BOT CAN OPEN ANY APP ON YOUR DEVICE GIVEN THE PACKAGE NAME OF THE APP WHICH YOU CAN FIND IN THE GOOGLE PLAY STORE
category.template: With these commands your bot canopen any app on your device, given the package name of the app, which you can find in the Google Play Store.

category.pattern: VARIABLES / WILD CARDS ARE USED TO CUSTOMIZE THE PATTERNS USED TO MATCH QUESTIONS TO COMMANDS . SEE THIS FORUM POST FOR HOW TO USE PATTERN OR WILDCARD RESPONSES . LIKE ALL RESPONSES YOU CAN ALSO ADD OTHER IDENTIFIERS SUCH AS KEYWORDS OR REQUIRED WORDS
category.template: Variables/wild cards are used to customize the Patterns used to match questions to commands. See this forum post for how to use pattern or wildcard responses. Like all responses, you can also add other identifiers such as keywords or required words.

category.pattern: BELOW YOU WILL FIND EXAMPLES FOR VARIOUS TYPES OF COMMANDS . YOU MAY USE OR CUSTOMIZE THESE BY REFERENCING THE KEYS AND VALUES . IF YOU WISH TO USE VOICE COMMANDS WITH YOUR BOT LIBRE PERSONAL ASSISTANT CREATE COMMANDS THAT MATCH HOW YOU WOULD SAY A DATE OR TIME NATURALLY ( EX : & #34 ; SET ALARM FOR 6 O & #39 ; CLOCK AM & #34 ; OR & #34 ; SET ALARM FOR 6 : 00 AM & #34 ; )
category.template: Below you will find examples for various types of commands. You may use or customize these by referencing the keys and values. If you wish to use voice commands with your Bot Libre Personal Assistant, create commands that match how you would say a date or time naturally (ex: "Set alarm for 6 o'clock am" or "Set alarm for 6:00 am").

category.pattern: SEE THIS FORUM POST IF YOU ARE UNFAMILIAR WITH TRAINING YOUR BOT USING RESPONSE LISTS
category.template: See this forum post if you are unfamiliar withtraining your bot using Response Lists.

category.pattern: I & #39 ; M INTERESTED IN READ A REPLY
category.template: I'm interested in read a reply.

category.pattern: WHEN I ASSIGN WORDS TO TOPICS AND THEN I TYPE IN FOR INSTANCE GNOSTICS AND THERE IS A TOPIC WITH RESPONSES ( AS SEEN IN THE CODE ABOVE ) THAT SHOULD CALL MY RESPONSES . BUT IT S NOT
category.template: When I assign words to topics, and then I type in for instance "gnostics" and there is a topic with responses (as seen in the code above), that should call my responses. But it's not.

category.pattern: I DON T KNOW IF IT IS THE LOGIC IN THE NON-COMMERCIAL VERSION CAUSING ME PROBLEMS OR IF IT IS MY CODE
category.template: I don't know if it is the logic in the non-commercial version causing me problems, or if it is my code.

category.pattern: HOWEVER I AM HAVING DIFFICULTY CALLING MY AIML FROM THE SCRIPTS WITH THESE BUTTONS THAT I HAVE PLACED IN THE GREETINGS
category.template: However, I am having difficulty calling my AIML from the scripts with these buttons that I have placed in the greetings.

category.pattern: THE < A / A > NEEDS TO GO ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE BUTTON
category.template: the needs to go on the outside of the button.

category.pattern: I FIGURED OUT PART OF THIS
category.template: I figured out part of this.

category.pattern: THANKS I WILL PROBABLY SUBSCRIBE TO COMMERCIAL AND GET BACK TO IT THEN
category.template: Thanks I will probably subscribe to commercial and get back to it then.

category.pattern: IF YOU ENCOUNTERED ANY ISSUES OR WOULD LIKE HELP SETTING UP YOUR BOT PLEASE EMAIL US AT [ EMAIL PROTECTED ] OR UPGRADE TO OUR PLATINUM SERVICE AND WE CAN BUILD YOUR BOT FOR YOU
category.template: If you encountered any issues, or would like help setting up your bot please email us at [emailprotected] or upgrade to our Platinum service and we can build your bot for you.

category.pattern: YOU NOW SHOULD BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW YOUR BOT RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS AND HOW TO BEST TRAIN YOUR BOT FOR YOUR DOMAIN USING TRAINING & CHAT LOGS RESPONSES KEYWORDS REQUIRED PREVIOUS TOPICS ETC . IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN LEARNING SCRIPTING YOU CAN PROGRAM MORE ADVANCED RESPONSES USING SELF OR AIML FROM THE SCRIPTS PAGE
category.template: You now should better understand how your bot responses to questions, and how to best train your bot for your domain using Training & Chat Logs, Responses, Keywords, Required, Previous, Topics, etc. If you are interested in learning scripting, you can program more advanced responses using Self or AIML from the Scripts page.

category.pattern: THE CHAT LOGS METHOD OF IMPORTING AIML ALLOWS THE AIML TO BE INTEGRATED WITH THE BOT & #39 ; S RESPONSES KNOWLEDGEBASE AND LEARNING . IMPORTING AIML AS A CHAT LOG IS THE BEST WAY TO IMPORT LARGE AIML FILES . YOU CAN ALSO IMPORT AIML FROM THE SCRIPTS PAGE IF YOU WANT THE AIML TO BE EXECUTED PRECISELY
category.template: The chat logs method of importing AIML allows the AIML to be integrated with the bot's responses, knowledgebase, and learning. Importing AIML as a chat log is the best way to import large AIML files. You can also import AIML from the Scripts page, if you want the AIML to be executed precisely.

category.pattern: AIML IS NORMALLY EXECUTED AS A SCRIPT WHERE EACH PATTERN EITHER MATCHES OR DOES NOT MATCH A QUESTION . WHEN IMPORTING AIML AS A CHAT LOG IT WILL NOT BE EXECUTED AS A SCRIPT . EACH AIML PATTERN WILL BE MATCHED BASED ON HOW WELL IT MATCHES THE QUESTION . FOR EXAMPLE THE PATTERN & #34 ; WHAT IS MEANING OF LIFE & #34 ; COULD MATCH THE QUESTION & #34 ; WHAT & #39 ; S THE PURPOSE OF LIFE & #34 ; IF IT WERE THE BEST MATCH . STANDARD AIML WOULD NOT PERFORM SUCH AS MATCH AS ONLY EXACT OR WILDCARD MATCHES ARE ALLOWED
category.template: AIML is normally executed as a script, where each pattern either matches or does not match a question. When importing AIML as a chat log, it will not be executed as a script. Each AIML pattern will be matched based on how well it matches the question. For example the pattern "what is meaning of life" could match the question "what's the purpose of life", if it were the best match. Standard AIML would not perform such as match, as only exact or wildcard matches are allowed.

category.pattern: AIML STANDS FOR THE ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE MARKUP LANGUAGE . IT IS AN XML STANDARD FOR DEFINING CHAT BOT RESPONSES . YOU CAN IMPORT ANY AIML FILE AS A CHAT LOG . THE BOT WILL LEARN ALL OF THE PATTERNS AND TEMPLATES AS QUESTIONS AND RESPONSES . IT WILL CONVERT ANY AIML TAGS IN THE TEMPLATE TO TEMPLATE RESPONSES USING SELF CODE AND USE WILDCARD PATTERNS FOR ANY AIML PATTERNS
category.template: AIML stands for the Artificial Intelligence Markup Language. It is an XML standard for defining chat bot responses. You can import any AIML file as a chat log. The bot will learn all of the patterns and templates as questions and responses. It will convert any AIML tags in the template to Template responses using Self code, and use wildcard Patterns for any AIML patterns.

category.pattern: IT WILL ALSO LOOKUP EACH WORD FOR ITS MEANING FROM WIKTIONARY AND PROCESS QUESTIONS AND ANSWER THROUGH ITS STATE MACHINES . FOR EXAMPLE THE QUESTION & #34 ; USER : WHAT IS THE EARTH & #34 ; WILL HAVE THE BOT LOOKUP IN FREEBASE ALL INFORMATION RELATED TO THE PLANET EARTH AND IMPORT THE INFORMATION INTO ITS BRAIN . COMPREHENSION WILL TAKE SIGNIFICANTLY LONGER TO IMPORT THE CHAT LOG SO ONLY USE THIS FOR SMALL CHAT LOG FILES THAT YOU WANT THE BOT TO LEARN FROM
category.template: It will also lookup each word for its meaning from Wiktionary, and process questions and answer through its state machines. For example the question "User: What is the Earth" will have the bot lookup in Freebase all information related to the planet Earth, and import the information into its brain. Comprehension will take significantly longer to import the chat log, so only use this for small chat log files that you want the bot to learn from.
